turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Benthoscope.
turn.2: Benthoscope The Benthoscope was a deep sea submersible designed by Otis Barton after the Second World War.
turn.4: He hired the Watson-Stillman Company, who had earlier constructed his and William Beebe's bathysphere to produce the new design of deep diving vessel, which was named from the Greek "benthos", meaning "bottom".
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: The Benthoscope was essentially similar to the bathysphere, but was built to withstand higher pressures, with a crush depth of 10,000 feet (3,048 m).
turn.7: What did it look like inside?
turn.8: Its internal diameter was 4.5 feet (1.4 m), and its wall thickness was 1.75 inches (44.5 mm).
turn.10: It weighed 7 tons (6,350 kg), an increase in weight of 1,600 pounds (726 kg) over the bathysphere.
turn.11: Were there any other views of the sub?
turn.12: Two windows of fused quartz were installed, one facing straight ahead and the other diagonally down.
